I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During the 2007 Country Programming Midterm Review Mission, the Government of the 
People’s Republic of China (PRC) requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to provide 
technical assistance (TA) to support the macro environmental strategy study and prepare a 
national strategy for developing sustainable energy crops.  At the request of the Government, 
ADB fielded a Fact-Finding Mission in Beijing during 5–8 June 2007, held discussions with 
representatives  of  the  Ministry  of  Agriculture  (MOA),  State  Environmental  Protection 
Administration (SEPA), and Ministry of Finance (MOF). During the discussions, the need for and 
the scope of a consolidated TA for national strategies for environmental management and 
energy conservation were confirmed.1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Over  the  last  25  years,  the  PRC  has  transformed  itself  from  a  closed  agricultural 
economy to a global industrial and economic powerhouse. The sustained and rapid economic 
growth resulting from this transformation has lifted hundreds of millions of people out of poverty 
and improved the standard of living of all citizens to varying degrees. However, the distribution 
of the gains has not been widespread or equitable, and they have come at a significant cost to 
the environment due to the accelerated exploitation of natural resources and massive increases 
in pollutant discharges. With the PRC’s population predicted to reach 1.45 billion, with gross 
domestic product of $4 trillion and urbanization of about 55% by 2020, the need to balance 
environmental protection and economic and social development is imperative.  
 
3.  The  environmental  challenges  facing  the  PRC  are  diverse  and  growing,  from  land 
degradation to water scarcity, and from air pollution to greenhouse gas emissions. The total 
emissions of major pollutants far exceed the environmental bearing capacity. Pollution problems 
adversely affecting water, air, soil, and solid wastes are significant. In addition, environmental 
pollution-related accidents seem to occur more frequently, ecological degradation is escalating, 
and  the  ecology  of  major  river  basins  in  various  regions  is  severely  threatened.  The 
environmental protection targets set in the 10th Five-Year Plan (FYP) have not been met, and in 
2006—under the 11th FYP period (2006–2010)—discharge of major pollutants shows no sign of 
reduction but instead has increased.2  
 
4.  The Government is determined to address the issues of environmental management and 
energy  conservation.  The  Government’s  11th  FYP  for  National  Economic  and  Social 
Development, which was approved by the National People’s Congress Conference in March 
2006,  included  a  detailed  discussion  of  the  issue  of  building  a  resource-efficient  and 
environment-friendly society, with focus on promoting energy conservation and strengthening 
the effort of pollution control. The 11th FYP also calls for resource-efficient agriculture and 
pollution prevention in the agriculture sector. There are many specific targets for the 11th FYP 
period, but the two most prominent are the reduction of energy intensity of gross domestic 
product by 20% and the reduction of the total pollution load by 10%. The PRC’s National 
Climate Change Programme, announced in June 2007, stressed the use of renewable energy 
including the development of biomass renewable energy (BRE) to reduce energy intensity and 
further contribute to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions.

5.  In this context, the Government is developing a macro environmental strategy and a 
strategy for BRE development. The macro environmental strategy refers to the strategy to 
address long-term fundamental issues concerning environmental protection. In recent years, 
research on environmental strategy has drawn ever-growing attention globally, and several 
countries  and  regional  organizations  including  Germany,  Japan,  United  States,  European 
Union,  and  Organization  for  Economic  Cooperation  and  Development  (OECD)  have 
successively formulated their own environmental strategies. In 2002, SEPA began a research 
program on a strategy for environmental security, which played a crucial role in guiding the 
development of related environmental chapters for the 11th FYP. In February 2007, SEPA 
obtained the State Council’s approval for the preparation of the macro environmental strategy 
study. One of the key challenges is how to manage the PRC’s environmental challenges using 
OECD experience.  
 
6.  BRE is a sensible and cost-effective way to address both rural energy gaps and the rural 
nonpoint source pollution problem. BRE is generated from animal wastes and plant biomass, 
and includes biogas, straw and stalk combustion and gasification, biomass power generation, 
and biofuels. The production of liquid biofuels from energy crops is one of the high priorities in 
the  11th  FYP.  The  Government  released  a  policy  document  in  November  2006  entitled 
Suggestions on the Implementation of Taxation Policies to Support Bioenergy Development, 
and an investment of about CNY3.2 billion is planned to support energy crops development. 
The National Development and Reform Commission recently promulgated a special program on 
ethanol and biofuel development for the 11th FYP period, prioritizing the production of ethanol 
from energy crops like cassava, sweet sorghum, etc., and setting a production target of 5.22 
million tons of ethanol annually during 2006–2010. 
 
7.  Although  biofuel  development  is  one  of  the  key  measures  to  conserve  energy  by 
reducing energy intensity, the Government is also aware of the necessity to balance biofuel 
development with food security, and ensure that biofuel development will neither impact the 
people’s grain consumption nor compete with food grain production for cultivated land. There is 
also the concern that the extensive use of energy crops for biofuel production may lead to a 
shortage of edible grains and feedstock supplies. Apart from the food security concern, there 
are also some environment-related issues facing the PRC including (i) the appropriate energy 
crops, locations, and environmental implications; (ii) the key environmental considerations (such 
as  water  availability,  nutrient  and  pesticide  applications,  carbon  benefits,  and  habitat 
preservation) in the production and distribution of energy crops; and (iii) appropriate agricultural 
practices suitable for ensuring soil quality, soil carbon, water quality, and wildlife population.  
 
8.  Strengthening the environment and energy conservation are the strategic areas in the 
country  strategy  and  program  update  (2007–2008)  for  the  PRC.  The  TA  will  assist  in  
developing  the  PRC’s  macro  environmental  strategy  and  preparing  a  national  strategy  for 
sustainable energy crops development, and will analyze international experiences on balancing 
economic growth and environment protection; environmental management of air, water, and 
ecosystems; and energy conservation, particularly the use of biofuel derived from energy crops 
development,  and make recommendations for the Government to consider. 
  
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
9.  The TA aims to contribute to PRC’s quest for sustainable development with balanced 
economic growth, environmental protection, and energy conservation. Specifically, the TA will 
support  PRC’s development of the macro environmental strategy and the national strategy for

3
sustainable  energy  crops  development.  The  TA  will  support  strategy  development  through 
surveys,  analysis,  assessments,  and  recommendations  covering  institutional,  financial,  and 
technical aspects. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.   
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  To attain the expected impact, two components have been identified: (i) support for the 
macro environmental strategy study, and (ii) preparing a national strategy for sustainable energy 
crops development.     
 
11.  Component  A:  Support  for  the  Macro  Environmental  Strategy  Study.  Over  60 
academicians  from  both  the  Chinese  Academy  of  Sciences  and  the  Chinese  Academy  of 
Engineering, and internationally and nationally renowned experts and scholars will be invited to 
carry  out  the  macro  environmental  study.  This  component  will  introduce  international 
experiences and lessons learned from developed countries and make recommendations for the 
selected thematic issues. The tasks under the component are the following.  
 
(i)  Conduct research on balancing environmental protection and economic growth in 
developed countries, and make practical recommendations for the PRC including 
(a) analysis of the relationship between environmental protection and economic 
growth, (b) analysis of the break-even point when environmental protection and 
economic growth are in harmony, and (c) ways to solve the conflict between 
economic growth and environmental protection.  
 
(ii)  Study developed countries’ experiences and lessons in managing air, water, and 
the  ecosystem;  and  give  specific  recommendations  for  environmental 
management in these areas in the PRC.  
 
(iii)  Study environmental policies and institutions in developed countries to shed light 
on how PRC could strengthen its institutional capacity, legal framework, and 
market mechanism for environmental protection. Specific focus should be on (a) 
development of environmental legislation and enforcement at national, regional, 
provincial,  and  local  levels;  and  (b)  market  instruments  for  environmental 
protection including labeling, pricing, insurance, securities, finance, taxation, and 
eco-compensation. 
  
12.  Component  B:  Preparing  a  National  Strategy  for  Sustainable  Energy  Crops 
Development. MOA completed a national survey on current agricultural wastes and marginal 
land resources suitable for energy crops development. The TA will assist MOA in preparing a 
national strategy with recommendations for short- and long-term strategic options covering 
2008–2020 for developing energy crops. The following tasks will be undertaken under this 
component.  
 
(i)  Assess energy crops development potential, i.e., (a) evaluate crops and crop 
species most suitable for various soil types, farming systems, and environment; 
(b) investigate and appraise water and land resources and adaptability, and 
recommend possible energy crops for the selected areas; (c) develop an energy 
crop distribution information base; and (d) investigate the global energy crop 
market and its impact on the national strategy.  
 
(ii)  Analyze the production and marketing of energy crops at the farm and sector 
levels. Specifically, (a) analyze the potential for production of various crops, labor

4   
needs,  financial  viability,  water  requirement,  energy  intensity,  harvesting  and 
processing, etc., in comparison with alternative food crops; and evaluate the 
financial feasibility of its production and marketing; (b) evaluate and recommend 
an optimal farmer-enterprise relationship model to secure a supply of high-quality 
feedstock and ensure that farmers receive a greater share of the profits from 
value-added  activities  (e.g.,  in  processing);  and  (c)  recommend  a  practical 
vertically-integrated enterprise production model for sustainable energy crops 
development including tax/policy incentives in the PRC. 
 
(iii)  Assess social and environmental impacts of energy crops development, including 
production and biofuel development and its influence on the food chain, and 
recommend adequate safeguard measures to mitigate the possible impact on 
food supplies and the environment.  
 
(iv)  Recommend a national strategy for energy crop development including (a) inter-
agency coordination mechanisms, (b) policy instruments, (c) regulatory protocols, 
and  (d)  investment  and  financial  mechanisms  to  promote  public-private 
partnerships. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The TA cost is estimated at $1,300,000 equivalent. ADB will finance $900,000 on a grant 
basis through its TA funding program. The Government will finance the remaining $400,000 
equivalent. The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  The  Ministry  of  Finance  (MOF)  is  the  Executing  Agency  for  the  TA.  SEPA  is  the 
Implementing  Agency  (IA)  for  component  A,  and  MOA  is  the  IA  for  component  B.  TA 
implementation will be closely coordinated with other key line agencies, such as the People’s 
Congress,  National  Development  and  Reform  Commission,  Ministry  of  Science  and 
Technology, Ministry of Land Resource Management, Ministry of Construction, Ministry of Water 
Resources, and  Ministry of Health.  
 
15.  The macro environmental strategy study has been approved by the State Council. A 
Leading Group has been established, headed by the President of the Chinese Academy of 
Engineering and comprising senior officials (at vice minister level) from various line agencies.3 
The Leading Group will provide overall guidance in implementing component A. A Steering 
Committee will be established in SEPA, chaired by the Director General of Legal and Policy 
Department and comprising senior officials of the departments for international cooperation, 
pollution  control,  ecological  conservation,  and  Foreign  Economic  Cooperation  Office.  A 
technical management office (TMO) will be established in the Foreign Economic Cooperation 
Office.

16.  In component B, the Steering Committee, comprising senior officials from various line 
agencies,4 chaired by the Vice Minister, will provide overall guidance for TA direction. The 
existing TMO of the ongoing TA 4810-PRC5 will be the TMO of the TA and responsible for 
carrying out day-to-day TA operations. The TMO director of TA 4810 will serve as head of the 
TMO and function as the overall TA coordinator. The Rural Energy Division of MOA, Rural 
Energy and Environment Institute,  Foreign Economic Cooperation Center, and the TMO, will 
work closely and be jointly responsible for coordinating  implementation activities among ADB, 
consultants, and related government agencies.  
 
17.  A team of international and national consultants will be recruited for 16 person-months 
and 48 person-months, respectively. The consultants for components A and B will be engaged 
by ADB on an individual basis, in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2007, as amended from time to time). Equipment to be purchased under the TA will be 
procured in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to 
time), and will be handed over to MOF upon completion of the TA. TA implementation will take 9 
months, from January 2008 to September 2008. Implementation progress will be monitored 
through the inception, interim, and final review meetings, workshops, and conferences. The 
training, workshop, and conference funds will be administered through MOF and an advance 
payment facility will be provided. The terms of reference of the consultants are in Appendix 3. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $900,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for the National Strategies for Environmental 
Management and Energy Conservation, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
 
A.   Component A: Support for the Macro Environmental Strategy Study 
 
1.  A team of international consultants with expertise in environmental economic analysis, 
environmental policy, and environmental management will be recruited as individuals for an 
estimated input of 9 person-months. A team of national consultants with expertise in water and 
air  pollution  and  prevention,  ecosystem  management,  and  environmental  institutional 
arrangement will be recruited for an estimated input of 24 person-months.  
 
  1.  Team Leader/Environmental Economist (international, 4 person-months)  
 
2.  The consultant, with the assistance of the deputy team leader, will work closely with the 
international and national consultants, and liaise with other international agencies supporting 
related works in partnership with the Asian Development Bank (ADB), especially the World 
Bank and United States Environmental Protection Agency. In addition, the consultant will carry 
out the following technical responsibilities. 
 
(i)  Develop  the  study  framework,  coordinate  the  individual  studies,  review  and 
consolidate individual reports, and organize workshops. 
(ii)  Review and assess international experiences on balancing economic growth and 
environmental protection, and prepare a report on international experience in the 
relation  between  economic  growth  and  environmental  protection  and  its 
implications for the People’s Republic of China (PRC).  
(iii)  Review  the  literature,  including  technical  assistances  (TAs)  provided  by  the 
World  Bank  and  ADB  for  environmental  management  in  the  PRC,  and 
summarize  lessons from those studies. 
(iv)  Supervise the national and international consultants in drafting and finalizing 
environmental management and economic instruments and other related reports 
(transfer procedure, capacity building, and training program, etc.); and review TA 
inception, midterm, and final reports, and revise chapters/sections, if necessary, 
to ensure that TA outputs are adequate in scope and quality. 
(v)  Organize and give presentations at workshops/seminars. 
(vi)  Assist  the  Executing  Agency  (EA)  to  coordinate  potential  public  relations, 
including media and events.  
(vii)  Consolidate all consultant reports into an overall TA report summarizing findings 
and experiences of developed countries and giving recommendations for the  
macro environmental strategy.  
(viii)  Draft and finalize the TA inception, medium-term, and final reports. 
(ix)  At the end of TA implementation, help the EA draft policy notes to be submitted 
to  the  State  Council,  recommending  further  policy  and  institutional  changes 
needed for environmental management. 
 
2.  Environmental Policy Specialist (international, 3 person-months) 
 
3.  The specialist will undertake these tasks. 
 
(i)  Study  institutional  development  for  environmental  protection  in  developed 
countries, particularly legal tools and market instruments, including development 
of environmental legislation, and international experiences in environmental law 
enforcement.

(ii)  Review and assess international experiences on pricing, financing, insurance, 
security, taxation, and eco-compensation that favor environmental protection.   
(iii)  Review  and  assess  the  existing  laws  and  enforcement  system,  and  identify  
potential challenges and opportunities for the PRC to enforce environmental 
requirements. 
(iv)  Identify the need for developing legislation or revising existing laws/regulations.  
(v)  Provide key inputs in preparing environmental management and environment-
economic  thematic  reports,  recommending  the  development  of  needed 
legislation  and innovative instruments. 
(vi)  Prepare environmental policy thematic reports.  
(vii)  Give workshop/seminar presentations and perform other related tasks  assigned 
by the team leader. 
 
3.  Environmental Management Specialist (international, 2 person-months) 
 
4.  The specialist will undertake these tasks. 
 
(i)  Review and assess international experiences and lessons of developed countries 
on (a) water pollution and prevention, (b) air pollution and prevention, and (c) 
ecosystem management. 
(ii)  Provide key inputs in preparing environmental policy and environment-economic 
thematic  reports,  recommending  the  needed  management  measures  for 
particular media (air, water, and ecosystem). 
(iii)  With  inputs  from  national  experts  (water,  air,  ecosystem,  and  environmental 
management), prepare an environmental management thematic report. 
(iv)  Give workshop/seminar presentations and perform other related tasks assigned 
by the team leader. 
 
4.  National  Consultant  Team  (24  person-months,  for  water  pollution  and 
prevention [6], air pollution and prevention [6], ecosystem management [6], and 
environmental institutional arrangement [6]) 
 
5.  A national deputy team leader will be selected to support the international team leader. 
The consultants will have the following responsibilities.  
 
(i)  Assess key issues on water pollution, air pollution, and ecosystem, including 
pollution sources, pollution structure, and geographical areas. 
(ii)  Review  the  authority  and  responsibilities  of  institutions  and  organizations 
involved in managing water, air, and the ecosystem, with specific attention to 
potential bottlenecks when implementing environmental rules and regulations. 
(iii)  Review lessons from implementing the 10th Five-Year Plan on water, air, and 
ecosystem management, and examine the implications of implementing the 11th 
Five-Year Plan and formulating macro environmental strategy on water, air, and 
the ecosystem. 
(iv)  In coordination with the international consultants, prepare an analysis highlighting 
the  strategy-level  strengths  and  weaknesses  of  the  existing  planning  and 
strategy for water, air, and ecosystem management in the PRC, and identify 
possible modifications that would adapt international best practices to the PRC.  
(v)  Conduct three seminars for water, air, and ecosystem management; provide an 
analysis  of  the  thematic  reports  from  the  international  consultant  team;  and 
suggest mechanisms that could be applied to the macro environmental strategy 
study.

B.  Component  B:  Preparing  a  National  Strategy  for  Sustainable  Energy  Crops 
Development 
 
6.  Component B will be carried out by a team of individual consultants. The TA will require 
7 person-months of international and 24 person-months of national consulting services.  
 
1.  Biomass  Energy  Development  Specialists  (international  team  leader,  4 
person-months; national deputy team leader, 7 person-months) 
 
7.  The team leader and the deputy team leader will demonstrate experience in preparing 
and managing bioenergy, particularly biofuel projects in the PRC and understanding of the 
PRC’s energy crops potential, biofuel, and related policies. They will coordinate all activities of 
the consultants during TA implementation, including liaising with the EA. The team leader will 
periodically report progress to the EA and ADB, and submit high-quality consolidated reports as 
specified in the terms of reference. In addition to their duties as team leader and deputy team 
leader, they will carry out these technical responsibilities.  
 
(i)  Finalize the TA approach, providing a detailed work plan and implementation 
schedule, and assign team members for the necessary work.  
(ii)  Analyze and evaluate how sustainable energy crops development can be closely 
integrated with planning activities for food security, rural development, ecological 
conservation, and energy conservation. 
(iii)  Work closely with other consultants, review and assess international experience 
in energy crops development and the implications for the PRC.  
(iv)  Provide leadership and guidance in designing and implementing a road map for 
energy crops development. Assist in the survey and analysis of energy crops 
resources and needs in rural areas. 
(v)  Identify institutional and policy barriers to farmers’ involvement in sustainable 
energy  crops  development,  and  make  recommendations  for  regulatory  or 
institutional changes that can ensure the participation of biofuel enterprises and 
farmers in energy crops development. 
(vi)  Assist the bioenergy technology specialist to conduct the cost-benefit analysis of 
various conversion technologies.   
(vii)  Draft and finalize a national strategy for sustainable energy crops development, 
covering (a) an interagency coordination mechanism, (b) policy instruments, (c) 
regulatory protocols, and (d) an investing and financing mechanism for promoting 
public-private partnerships. 
(viii)  Draft and finalize the energy crops development program, including its short- 
(2010), medium- (2015), and long-term (2020) goals, and covering provincial 
distribution, investment needs, and other requirements.  
(ix)  Draft and finalize the TA inception, medium-term, and final reports for ADB.  
(x)  At the end of TA implementation, help the EA draft policy notes to be submitted 
to the State Council, recommending policy and institutional changes needed for 
sustainable energy crops development.  
(xi)  Organize  and  hold  the  three  consultation  workshops,  encourage  active 
participation by steering committee members, and give presentations.

12   Appendix 3 
 
2.  Bioenergy Economists (international, 1.5 person-months; national, 3 person-
months) 
 
8.  The economists will undertake these tasks. 
 
(i)  Review the current status of liquid biofuel and ethanol use in the PRC to identify 
the share of biofuel in the total energy supply. Address future trends in biofuel 
demand. 
(ii)  Make a matching analysis of energy crops resources and biofuel demands, and 
evaluate  the  gap  between  them.  Identify  opportunities  for  energy  crops 
development in selected provinces and regions. 
(iii)  Identify and recommend sound and environment-friendly technological pathways 
linking resources and demand in rural areas, and establish a biofuel development 
road map in the selected regions that can serve as the basis for the sustainable 
energy crops national strategy and program. 
(iv)  Develop demand projections for various biofuels that can be generated from 
different agricultural crops, including ethanol (corn, sugarcane, sweet sorghum, 
sweet potato, cassava) and biodiesel (soy, rape, jatropha, sunflower). 
(v)  Develop a cost and performance database of biofuel conversion technologies, 
and do an economic cost-benefit analysis of these technologies in cooperation 
with the environmental and social development specialists. 
(vi)  Assist in surveying energy crops resources, analyze the energy crops supply 
system, and address future development trends.  
(vii)  Prepare related chapters or sections of TA documents and reports, and conduct 
other related work assigned by the team leader/deputy team leader. 
 
3.  Agronomists (international, 1.5 person-months; national, 3 person-months) 
 
9.  The agronomists will undertake these tasks. 
  
(i)  Evaluate crops and crop species grown in various soil types, farming systems, 
and environment that are most suitable for different liquid biofuel applications. 
(ii)  Investigate and appraise water and land resources in selected provinces, and 
recommend possible energy crops adapted to the selected areas considering key 
factors such as economic viability, suitability for different biofuel applications, 
yield, input requirements, crop versatility, drought and pest resistance potential, 
competing uses, price volatility, and opportunity costs. 
(iii)  Analyze the various crops’ potential production, labor needs, water requirement, 
energy intensity, harvesting, processing, and distribution, etc. 
(iv)  Assist  the  energy  crop  resource  specialist  in  surveying  energy  crop  types, 
resource availability, and distribution in the selected provinces, counties, and 
villages. 
(v)  Participate  in  workshop/seminar  presentations,  prepare  related  chapters  or 
sections of TA documents and reports, and conduct other related tasks assigned 
by the team leader/deputy team leader.

Appendix 3  13 
4.  Environment Specialist (national, 5 person-months) 
 
10.  The specialist will undertake these tasks. 
 
(i)  Assess the environmental implication of energy crops production and issues 
such  as  feedstock  choice,  land  use  and  soil  fertility;  impact  on  grasslands, 
tropical forests, wetlands, and other biodiverse ecosystems; impact on water 
quality and availability; and impacts on climate change mitigation.  
(ii)  Recommend adequate safeguard measures to mitigate the possible impact on 
the environment. 
(iii)  Review current environmental policies and regulations related to energy crops 
development. Make recommendations for regulatory or institutional changes that 
could improve the effectiveness of policies and regulations with regard to the 
energy  crops  market;  and  for  integration  of  water,  soil,  and  biodiversity 
conservation regulations with energy crops development. 
(iv)  Recommend  institutional  coordination  mechanisms  to  strengthen  interministry 
cooperation on water, soil, and biodiversity conservation; pollution control; and 
energy crops development. 
(v)  Identify  the  global  environmental  benefits  of  the  national  energy  crops 
development program, and develop a plan for (a) pursuing Global Environment 
Facility financing sources, and (b) applying clean development mechanism. 
(vi)  Participate in workshop and seminar presentations, prepare related chapters or 
sections of TA documents and reports, and conduct other related tasks  assigned 
by the team leader/deputy team leader. 
 
5.  Energy Crops Resource Specialist (national, 2 person-months)   
 
11.  The specialist will undertake these tasks. 
 
(i)  With  the  assistance  of  the  agronomist,  survey  energy  crop  types,  resource 
availability, and distribution in the selected provinces, counties, and villages. 
(ii)  Develop information on energy crop distribution based on the selected provinces, 
including the type of crops, acreage and availability of land, the suitability for 
planting  and  transport  of  energy  crops,  conversion  technologies,  and  other 
development potentials.  
(iii)  Participate  in  workshop/seminar  presentations,  prepare  related  chapters  or 
sections of TA documents and reports, and conduct other related tasks assigned 
by the team leader/deputy team leader. 
 
6.  Social and Rural Development Specialist (national, 4 person-months) 
 
12.  The specialist will undertake these tasks.  
 
(i)  Assist  other  consultants  in  reviewing  the  current  status  of  energy  crops 
development and the existing relationship between enterprises and farmers in 
energy crops development. 
(ii)  Recommend an optimal farmer-enterprise relationship model to secure a high-
quality supply of feedstock and ensure that farmers receive a greater share of the 
profits from value-added activities (e.g., processing and distribution). 
(iii)  Review current poverty reduction policies and regulations related to energy crops 
and sustainable rural development.

14   Appendix 3 
(iv)  Evaluate biofuel development and its influence on the food chain. This analysis 
needs  to  review  the  country’s  food  security  policy,  conduct  surveys  of  poor 
households (urban and rural), and analyze the impact on food availability as well 
as on food access.  
(v)  Recommend adequate safeguard measures to mitigate the possible impact on 
food supplies and the environment. 
(vi)  Participate in workshop/seminar presentations, prepare related chapters/sections 
of TA documents/reports, and conduct other related tasks assigned by the team 
leader/deputy team leader. 
 
C.  Reporting Requirements 
 
13.  The consultants will submit the following reports: (i) an inception report within 1 month of 
the start of the TA, (ii) an interim report 4 months after the TA starts, (iii) a draft final report 8 
months after the TA starts, and (iv) a final report at the conclusion of the TA. The final report will 
reflect  comments  made  by  government  agencies,  ADB,  and  other  relevant  parties.  The 
consultants will submit all reports in English and Chinese languages—six copies each in English 
and Chinese to the Government, and three copies of the English version to ADB, including one 
electronic copy in a compact disc.
